head.title: Metal-Induced Self-Assembly Template for Controlled Growth of ZIF-8 Nanorods | Chemistry of Materials

meta.content: Metal-Induced Self-Assembly Template for Controlled Growth of ZIF-8 Nanorods

A comprehensive method to prepare a one-dimensional (1D) metal–organic framework (MOF) has attracted research interest because the 1D MOFs are useful as precursor materials for the preparation of highly porous carbon nanorods with outstanding electrical conductivity and mechanical strength, making them particularly suitable for electrochemical applications. Herein, the synthesis of 1D zeolitic imidazolate framework-8 (ZIF-8) nanorods is reported using the metal-induced self-assembly templates of imidazole-functionalized perylenetetracarboxylic diimide (PDI-Hm). The size of PDI-Hm self-assemblies is finely tuned on the nanoscale by the method of metal-induced self-assembly whose surface-exposed metal ions were further exploited as nucleation sites for the growth of ZIF-8. Versatility of the metal-induced self-assembly template for the growth of other 1D MOFs was demonstrated using various transition-metal ions on demands. The size-controlled ZIF-8 nanorods were applied further as a precursor material to produce porous, nitrogen-doped carbon nanorods through the carbonization. The carbon nanorods show decent supercapacitor electrode material performance, with enhanced specific capacitance of 292.2 F g–1, because of their unique 1D feature with reduced charge transfer resistance and large specific surface area derived from a downscaled template size under 100 nm.

div.span: Supporting Info (1)
SUBJECTS:

div.p:
A comprehensive method to prepare a one-dimensional (1D) metal–organic framework (MOF) has attracted research interest because the 1D MOFs are useful as precursor materials for the preparation of highly porous carbon nanorods with outstanding electrical conductivity and mechanical strength, making them particularly suitable for electrochemical applications. Herein, the synthesis of 1D zeolitic imidazolate framework-8 (ZIF-8) nanorods is reported using the metal-induced self-assembly templates of imidazole-functionalized perylenetetracarboxylic diimide (PDI-Hm). The size of PDI-Hm self-assemblies is finely tuned on the nanoscale by the method of metal-induced self-assembly whose surface-exposed metal ions were further exploited as nucleation sites for the growth of ZIF-8. Versatility of the metal-induced self-assembly template for the growth of other 1D MOFs was demonstrated using various transition-metal ions on demands. The size-controlled ZIF-8 nanorods were applied further as a precursor material to produce porous, nitrogen-doped carbon nanorods through the carbonization. The carbon nanorods show decent supercapacitor electrode material performance, with enhanced specific capacitance of 292.2 F g
–1
, because of their unique 1D feature with reduced charge transfer resistance and large specific surface area derived from a downscaled template size under 100 nm.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
One-dimensional (1D) metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) attract wide research interests because of their unique structure and uniform porosity, which enable their applications in gas storage/separation,
(1)
catalysis,
(2)
and energy storage.
(3,4)
Zeolitic imidazolate framework-8 (ZIF-8), a subdivision of MOF, is a prototypical material of MOF structures because of its simple synthetic process under mild conditions.
(5,6)
The majority of ZIF-8 research has focused on the preparation of 0D spherical
(7)
or 2D planar structures
(8−10)
for use in gas separation membranes. However, only limited numbers of 1D ZIF-8 fibers have been reported using passive templates, such as metal,
(11−13)
metal oxide,
(14)
electro-spun polymeric microfibers,
(4,15,16)
or porous polymer membranes.
(17)
For practical purposes, however, these passive template-based syntheses have disadvantages, such as the requirement for the pre-treatment providing affinity to the ZIF-8, difficulties in scalability, and limitations in sizing down to the nanoscale. Therefore, the development of a new class of synthetic approaches to overcome these drawbacks remains a challenge.

The appropriate size-controlled 1D templates for the 1D MOF synthesis can be prepared by the self-assembly of small molecules.
(18−20)
For instance, Wang et al. produced fibrous HKUST, by using a template consisting of a nanofibrillar bolaamphiphile assembly containing surface-exposed hydrophilic groups that acted as binding sites for copper species of the HKUST.
(21)
Amphiphilic perylenetetracarboxylic diimides (PDI) derivatives are promising self-assembling molecules
(22−24)
with assembled structures that provide suitable active templates for the controlled growth of MOFs. Specifically, PDI derivatives functionalized with metal-coordinating ligands can form well-defined supramolecular structures via a metal-induced self-assembly.
(25,26)
This metal-induced self-assembly strategy is beneficial not only for the size control of the PDI assembly templates on the nanoscale but also for the facilitated synthesis of MOFs by providing nucleation sites of metal species on the template surfaces.

In the present work, the size-controlled ZIF-8 nanorods, a prototype of the MOF nanorod, are prepared by templating the metal-induced PDI-Hm self-assemblies and are applied for the precursor materials of porous carbon nanorods (
Scheme 1
). In detail, a bolaform imidazole-functionalized PDI-derivative (PDI-Hm) self-assembles by coordination with Zn
2+
ions to form fibrous structures on the nanoscale (ZnP nanorods) with finely-tuned dimensions. The ZIF-8 then grows on the surfaces of the size-controlled ZnP nanorods to produce
[email protected]
core–shell (PZ) nanorods. The versatility of the active PDI-Hm self-assembly template is demonstrated further by the synthesis of other MOF (ZIF-67 and HKUST-1) nanorods utilizing Co
2+
and Cu
2+
as the coordinating metal ions. To take advantages of 1D-architectured MOF with a large specific surface area originated from the downscaled template, prepared PZ nanorods are converted to nitrogen-doped mesoporous carbon (PZC) nanorods via carbonization for use in the fabrication of supercapacitor electrodes. These PZC nanorods in various sizes reveal an enhancement in the specific capacitance (
C
S
) with the decreasing nanorod size, thus demonstrating the importance of the size-controlled template with designer activity for the porous materials.
Scheme 1. Schematic Illustrations of Size-Controllable PDI-Hm Self-Assemblies and Preparation of the 1D ZIF-8 Nanorods Using the Self-Assembly Templates

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
As shown in
Scheme 1
, the molecular building block of
N
,
N
′-bis(histamine)-3,4,9,10-perylenetetracarboxylic diimide (PDI-Hm) is a bolaform amphiphile in which the aromatic perylene skeleton forms aggregates via aromatic stacking, while the imidazole groups at each end provide hydrophilicity that allows the molecule to dissolve in polar solvents and guide the molecular ordering. In the present work, metal-induced PDI-Hm self-assemblies (designated ZnP;
Figure
1
a) in different sizes were prepared by mixing a methanolic solution of Zn(NO
3
)
2
(25 mM) with PDI-Hm solutions at various concentrations in 1:9 v/v HCl/methanol. Through the coordination of Zn to the imidazole of PDI-Hm along with the aromatic stacking of perylene segments, four distinct ZnP nanorod assemblies, designated ZnP1–ZnP4, were prepared under the preparation conditions shown in
Table S1
.

div.p:
Figure 1. ZnP self-assemblies produced in the present study: (a) schematic illustration of the ZnP nanorod formation via metal-induced self-assembly of PDI-Hm; (b) FT-IR spectra of the PDI-Hm molecules and self-assembled ZnP nanorods. (c–f) SEM images of the ZnP nanorods obtained at PDI-Hm concentrations of 0.1, 0.25, 0.5 and 0.75 mg mL
–1
(designated ZnP1–ZnP4, respectively) at a constant Zn(NO
3
)
2
concentration of 25 mM (inset: size distribution of ZnP nanorods), and (g) average diameter of ZnP self-assemblies.

div.div:
The central point of the metal-induced self-assembly is the coordination of the metal ion with imidazole of PDI-Hm. To assess the Zn and imidazole coordination, the ZnP nanorods were examined by Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy (
Figure
1
b), which revealed that the peaks of the out-of-plane π vibrations of the imidazole NH and the in-plain vibration of the imidazole rings at 634 and 852 cm
–1
were shifted to 626 and 858 cm
–1
, respectively, after zinc coordination.
(27,28)
These peak shifts were observed in every ZnP nanorod regardless of the concentration of PDI-Hm, suggesting that the PDI-Hm molecules were organized by the Zn-imidazole coordination. As indicated in
Figures
1
c–f and
S1
, the size of the ZnP nanorods was controlled by the concentrations of zinc ions and PDI-Hm that regulate the formation of the ZnP self-assemblies.
(29)
Generally, the resulting ZnP nanorods became shorter and thinner as the concentrations of both Zn and PDI-Hm were increased, due to the increased nucleation of the nanorod. Notably, for the range of PDI-Hm concentrations used in the present study, the diameters of the resulting ZnP nanorods ranged from 50 to 700 nm, and their lengths ranged from 1 to 100 μm (
Figures
1
g and
S1
), which suggests controllability of the nanorod dimensions to some extent. Hence, ZnP fibers with diameters of 700, 400, 100, and 50 nm were produced by using various concentrations of PDI-Hm with a constant Zn concentration of 25 mM, and then were used as templates for the preparation of ZIF-8 nanorods in controlled sizes.

The produced ZnP nanorods had high crystallinity indicative of the ordered arrangement of the PDI-Hm molecules. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) analyses, as shown in
Figure
2
a,c, show that the
d
-spacing of the ZnP assemblies between the perylene skeletons is 3.46 Å, which is in the range of the π–π stacking distances (3.2–3.7 Å) for previously reported self-assembled PDI derivatives.
(30,31)
The other two major dimensions of 14.38 and 7.55 Å are assigned to the half of longitudinal edge-to-edge and the side-to-side packing distances, respectively.
(30,32,33)

div.p: Figure 2. Characterization of ZnP self-assemblies: (a) XRD patterns of the ZnP nanorods (the characteristic peaks of PDI-Hm assemblies assigned to the major intermolecular spacing are marked with asterisks); (b) UV–vis spectra of ZnP4 and the PDI-Hm monomer, and (c) simulated molecular arrangement of the self-assembled PDI-Hm, indicating the intermolecular spacing as reconstructed from the XRD data.

div.div:
The aromatic stacking of the PDI-Hm molecules in the ZnP nanorods was further investigated by UV–vis spectroscopy, and the results are presented in
Figures
2
b and
S2
. Here, the solution of PDI-Hm molecules in 1:9 v/v 0.1 N HCl/methanol displays the characteristic absorption peaks at 520 and 480 nm corresponding to the vibronic 0 → 0 and 0 → 1 of the π–π* transition. Moreover, the relative intensity of these peaks (
A
0→0
/
A
0→1
= 1.73) is larger than 1, thus demonstrating the presence of the PDI-Hm molecules as the monomeric species.
(34)
After the self-assembly, the monomeric peaks of PDI-Hm are drastically reduced (
A
0→0
/
A
0→1
= 1.10) and a new characteristic peak appears at 564 nm. Both the change in the relative peak intensity and the appearance of a new peak are definitive signs of J-type aggregation of the PDI-Hm.
(35−37)

The PZ nanorods were then prepared by growing ZIF-8 on the surfaces of the ZnP nanorod templates. The Zn ions on the ZnP nanorods functioned as ZIF-8 nucleation sites by coordinating with 2-methylimidazole to facilitate the growth of ZIF-8. Nucleation of the ZIF-8 on the whole surface of the ZnP nanorod template was observable from the scanning electron microscopy (SEM) image taken at the early stages of the ZIF-8 deposition process (
Figure S3
). As indicated in
Figures
3
b–e and
S3
, further additions of Zn(NO
3
)
2
and 2-methylimidazole to the ZnP nanorod suspension produced PZ nanorods with ZIF-8 layer thicknesses of 64–71 nm. The size-controlled active ZnP nanorod produced 1D ZIF-8 nanorods with high uniformity, as shown in
Figure
3
f,g. The XRD patterns, as shown in
Figure
3
h, indicate that the crystalline structure of the ZIF-8 layer on the PZ nanorod is largely consistent with that of the particulate ZIF-8 crystals prepared in solution without ZnP templates. However, distortion of the ZnP crystalline structure by the ZIF-8 layer is observable from the PZ nanorods containing relatively large ZnP cores. Shifts in the diffraction peaks of the ZnP core are observed for the PZ1 and PZ2 samples, which have much smaller ZIF-8 layer thicknesses (∼70 nm) compared to that of the ZnP core (∼400 or 700 nm). The intact ZnP has unit cell dimensions of 14.38 Å (2θ = 6.14°) and 7.55 Å (2θ = 11.7°), which were changed to 15.2 Å (2θ = 5.82°) and 6.6 Å (2θ = 13.48°) after deposition of ZIF-8. These changes in the unit cell dimension confirm that the organized structure of the PDI-Hm molecules was altered by the formation of the ZIF-8 layer. It is speculated that the metal–ligand coordination is strong enough to distort the organized structure of the PDI-Hm assembly.
(38,39)
Moreover, the change in the intermolecular distance corroborates the heterogeneous nucleation and growth of ZIF-8 that is not physically attached to the ZnP template. Note that the disappearance of ZnP peaks (marked * in
Figure
3
h) in PZ3 and PZ4 is caused by the much larger volume of ZIF-8 than that of ZnP.

div.p: Figure 3. Properties of PZ nanorods: (a) schematic illustration of the PZ nanorod synthesis using the ZnP nanorod template on which ZIF-8 is nucleated; (b–e) SEM images of the PZ nanorods prepared by templating ZnP nanorods in various sizes (scale bar: 500 nm (b–d); 200 nm (e)); (f,g) SEM images of PZ4 nanorods at low magnification; (h) XRD patterns of the PZ nanorods; (i) nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms, and (j) the pore size distribution of the PZ nanorods.

div.div:
The porosities of the various PZ nanorods were determined from the N
2
adsorption–desorption isotherms, as shown in
Figure
3
i. The all PZ nanorods display type 1 isotherms of the typical ZIF-8 microporous structures. Moreover, the pore size distributions, as shown in
Figures
3
j and
S5
, indicate a pore size of ∼1 nm for PZ nanorods, which clearly originates from the ZIF-8, with mesopores in the size range of 2–5 nm derived from the ZnP template. These results are summarized in
Table S3
and demonstrate that, due to the micropores in the ZIF-8 layers, the surface area of the PZ nanorods increases with the decrease in ZnP core size. This further indicates that the surface area of the PZ nanorod is mostly determined by the ZIF-8 layer rather than the ZnP nanorod template. Hence, the small ZnP nanorod template is advantageous for the preparation of porous PZ nanorods with large surface areas.

To demonstrate the versatility of the PDI-Hm self-assembly template for the 1D MOF synthesis, ZIF-67 and HKUST-1 nanorods were prepared using the Co
2+
- and Cu
2+
-induced PDI-Hm nanorod templates, respectively. In the same fashion of ZnP preparation, Co
2+
-induced (CoP), and Cu
2+
-induced (CuP) self-assemblies of PDI-Hm were produced, and then were exploited for active templates to facilitate nucleation and growth of ZIF-67 and HKUST-1, respectively (
Figure
4
a,b). As shown in
Figure
4
c,d, 1D-architectured ZIF-67 and HKUST-1 are well prepared with template sizes of under 100 nm. The XRD patterns, as shown in
Figure S6
, also confirm the successful synthesis of 1D ZIF-67 and HKUST-1. The successful production of ZIF-67 and HKUST-1 nanorods supports the wide applicability of the metal-induced self-assembly of PDI-Hm as active templates whose surface-exposed metal ions are feasibly exploited for the nucleation/growth of heterogeneous substances.

div.p:
Figure 4. PDI-Hm self-assemblies induced by other transition metal ions for the synthesis of 1D MOFs: (a,b) SEM images of Co
2+
and Cu
2+
-induced self-assembled PDI-Hm nanorods (CoP and CuP, respectively); (c)
[email protected]
, and (d)
[email protected]
nanorods grown on the PDI-Hm nanorod templates.

div.div:
The 1D mesoporous carbon nanorods obtained from the PZ nanorods are suitable for the electrode materials for the supercapacitor because of their large surface to volume ratio, interconnected mesopores facilitating electron/ion transport, and high electrical conductivity originating from the 1D architecture.
(3,4,40−42)
Encouraged by the 1D ZIF-8 nanofiber synthesis with a finely tuned 1D morphology and the enhanced specific surface area derived from the downscaled template size compared to the previously reported method using an electrospun polymer template,
(4)
the mesoporous carbon (PZC) nanorods were produced by carbonization of the PZ nanorods under a nitrogen atmosphere and applied to the electrode material of the supercapacitor to demonstrate the advantages of 1D MOF as a precursor material (
Figures
5
and
S7
). The nanorod morphology was maintained without any fractures, thus demonstrating the stability of the PZ nanorod against thermal stress. As indicated in
Figure S7
, the mesoporous structure of the PZ nanorods was also maintained in the PZC nanorod, with some pores being visible on the surface. The XRD patterns of the PZC nanorods, as shown in
Figure
5
f, reveal two broad peaks at 2θ = 25° (002) and 44° (101) that are representative of the typical graphitic carbons, thus indicating the transformation of the carbon components of ZIF-8 and PDI-Hm into crystalline carbons.
(3)
In addition, as indicated by the scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) and atomic mapping images, as shown in
Figure S8
, the carbon and nitrogen atoms are uniformly distributed along the PZC nanorod. The graphitic order of the PZC nanorod is further verified by the Raman spectra, as shown in
Figure
5
g, where the signature peaks of the graphitic carbon D and G bands are observed at 1338 and 1585 cm
–1
. These are assigned to the in-plane A
1g
zone-edge mode and the doubly degenerate zone center E
2g
mode, respectively.
(3)
In addition, the broad peak corresponding to the second-order D band appeared in the range of 2500–3000 cm
–1
. The intensity ratio of the D band to the G band (
I
D
/
I
G
) was 1.08 for all the PZC carbon nanorods, thus confirming that all of the PZC carbon nanorods have the same graphitic order.

div.p:
Figure 5. Carbonization of the PZ nanorods to produce the porous carbon (PZC) nanorods: (a) schematic illustration of the mesoporous carbon nanorod preparation; (b–e) PZC nanorods with various sizes: (b) PZC1 (
d
≈ 820 nm), (c) PZC2 (
d
≈ 460 nm), (d) PZC3 (
d
≈ 166 nm), and (e) PZC4 (
d
≈ 131 nm); (f) XRD patterns of the carbon nanorods; (g) Raman spectra; (h) contents of nitrogen in various states; (i) nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherm, and (j) pore size distribution.

div.div:
The nitrogen species in the PZC nanorods were analyzed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and the results are presented in
Figure
5
h and
Table S4
. With ZIF-8 as the primary source of nitrogen, increasing quantities of nitrogen dopants are observed with the increase in the relative size of the ZIF-8 layer. In detail, deconvolution of the PZC N 1s spectra revealed the presence of the nitrogen in four different states, namely: pyridinic N (N-6), pyrrolic/pyrridonic N (N-5), quaternary N (N-4), and oxidic N (
Figure S9
and
Table S5
).
(43,44)
Among these, the N-6 and N-5 groups are crucial for the electrical function: N-6 acts as an electrochemically active site to induce Faradaic capacitance, while N-5 is involved in the charge mobility and good electron-donor characteristics, thus generating the electrical double layer capacitor (EDLC) function.
(45)
The contents of N-6 and N-5 species were also found to increase gradually with increasing the relative size of the ZIF-8 layer on the ZnP template.
(45−47)
Taken together, these results indicate that ZIF-8 is crucial in determining the doped nitrogen contents of the PZC nanorods and in generating electrically active nitrogen species.

The N
2
adsorption–desorption isotherms, as shown in
Figure
5
i, display type IV curves, thus indicating the generation of mesopores in the PZC nanorods after carbonization. This is probably due to the high-temperature decomposition of the organic ligand and the evaporation of Zn in ZIF-8. Meanwhile, the pore size distributions, as shown in
Figure
5
j, indicate that PZC1 has only mesopores (
d
= 2–10 nm), whereas PZC2, PZC3, and PZC4 have both mesopores and micropores (
d
≈ 1 nm). The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) specific surface area summarized in
Table S6
also demonstrates that the surface area of the PZC nanorod increases as the size of the ZnP template decreases, in agreement with the properties of the PZ nanorods.

The large surface area and unique interconnected mesoporous architecture of the PZC nanorods are appropriate for application in the EDLC electrode. Herein, the impact of the 1D architecture and the reduced template size were determined by examining and comparing the electrochemical properties of the PZC nanorods with those of the carbonized ZIF-8 nanoparticles (ZIF-8C). The structures and properties of ZIF-8C are provided in
Figure S10
and
Table S6
. The cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves of the samples (
Figure
6
a) each displayed a nearly rectangular shape, thus implying classical capacitive behavior of the EDLC with a small pseudo-capacitive contribution from the doped nitrogen of the PZC nanorods. In
Figure S11
, the classical capacitor CV curves were observed at a scan rate of 5–200 mV s
–1
. The PZC4 displayed the best capacitive property, presumably due to its large specific surface area.

div.p:
Figure 6. Electrochemical properties of the PZC nanorods as electrode materials: (a) CV; (b) GCD curves; (c) gravimetric specific capacitances calculated from the discharge curves of the PZCs; (d) cycling performance of PZC4 at 10 A g
–1
(inset: GCD curves at first cycle and 5000th cycle); (e) gravimetric specific capacitance and BET surface area (inset: specific surface area normalized capacitance), and (f) Nyquist plots of PZC nanorods (inset: magnified Nyquist plots).

div.div:
The EDLC function was confirmed by the galvanostatic charge–discharge (GCD) curves at various current densities from 0.5 to 20 A g
–1
(
Figures
6
b and
S11
). These curves were then used to calculate the specific capacitances (
C
S
), as presented in
Figure
6
c. PZC4 displays the highest
C
S
of 292.2 F g
–1
at a discharge current density of 0.5 A g
–1
and retains 60% of its capacitance at a high current density of 20 A g
–1
. This is comparable to the specific capacitance of previously reported carbonic electrode materials (
Table S7
). In addition, an examination of the cycling performance of PZC4 at 10 A g
–1
(
Figure
6
d) indicates a capacitance decay of only 4.1% after 5000 cycles, thus demonstrating excellent recycling capability. In contrast to the high
C
S
of PZC4, the other PZC nanorods and the carbonized ZIF-8 display lower
C
S
of <180 F g
–1
(
Figure
6
c). This is because the specific surface area is critical in determining the
C
S
value of the EDLC. This relationship between gravimetric specific capacitance and the BET surface area of the ZIF-8 materials is clearly indicated in
Figure
6
e. The effect of the architecture upon
C
S
is particularly notable considering that, in spite of its much larger surface area, ZIF-8C displayed an inferior
C
S
to that of PZC4. This shows clearly the advantages of the 1D nanorods over 0D nanoparticles in facilitating electron/ion transportation through the interconnected mesoporous architecture and the intrinsic electrical conductivity of the 1D nanorods. As indicated by the inset in
Figure
6
e, once the influence of the surface area on the capacitance is accounted for via the specific surface area normalized capacitance (
C
A
, where
C
A
=
C
S
/specific surface area), the PZC2–PZC4 nanorods show much higher
C
A
values (52.3 μF cm
–2
) than the ZIF-8C (15.1 μF cm
–2
). This superior
C
A
of the PZC nanorods over that of ZIF-8C further demonstrates the relevance of the 1D geometry.
(4,48−50)
Moreover, the data in
Table S7
indicate that the
C
A
values of the PZC nanorods are much higher than the values of 5–21.2 μF cm
–2
previously reported for 0D materials
(49,51)
and are comparable to those of other 1D carbon materials with high
C
A
.

Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was then preformed to account for the higher
C
S
of PZC compared to that of ZIF-8C. For each sample, the Nyquist plots, as shown in
Figure
6
f, display semicircles with the high-frequency Warburg diffusion lines and straight lines at low frequencies, thus indicating the purely capacitive behavior. The EIS data were then fitted to an equivalent electrical circuit model (
Figure S12
) to evaluate the important electrical parameters of charge transfer resistance (
R
CT
) and equivalent series resistance (
R
S
). The
R
CT
represents the resistance at the electrode material/current collector interface and the electrode/electrolyte interface, whereas
R
S
incorporates the intrinsic resistance of the active material, the ionic resistance of electrolyte, and the contact resistance.
(48,52,53)
The results summarized in
Table S8
indicate smaller
R
CT
values for the PZC compared to those of ZIF-8C because of the fast electron/ion transport through the interconnected mesopores of the PZC. Moreover, the smaller
R
S
value for PZC indicates the enhanced electrical conductivity of the 1D geometry, which provides an electron pathway with reduced charge transfer resistance (e.g., inter-particle resistance).
(48,49)
In addition to the low
R
CT
and
R
S
values, the straight lines in the low-frequency region of the Nyquist plots of the PZC nanorods are seen to be stiffer than that of the ZIF-8C, indicating faster ion diffusion through the electrolyte in the PZC nanorods than in the ZIF-8C nanoparticles.
(54)
All these observations account for the high
C
A
of the PZC nanorods in spite of the small specific surface areas.

A symmetric solid-state supercapacitor was fabricated by sandwiching a poly(vinyl alcohol) (PVA)–H
2
SO
4
–soaked glass membrane filter paper between the PZC4 electrodes, as shown in
Figure S13
. CV reveals rectangular curves in the range of 0–0.8 V, demonstrating the general EDLC supercapacitor behavior. In addition, the GCD profiles show a symmetric charge–discharge behavior at various current densities from 0.5 to 20 A g
–1
. The device exhibits a specific capacitance of 57.3 F g
–1
at 0.5 A g
–1
, 49.2% of which is retained at a high current density of 20 A g
–1
. Here, in order to simulate the demands of practical use, three single supercapacitors were connected in series to turn on a red LED. This result demonstrated the feasibility of the PZC supercapacitor to scale up the power output by the combination of several stacked capacitors.
(55)
The gravimetric energy density of the PZC4 device was 5.1 W h kg
–1
at a power density of 210.0 W kg
–1
, comparable to other carbon-based electrode materials (
Figure S14
).

div.div: In summary, ZIF-8 nanorods were successfully prepared by templating metal-induced self-assemblies of the imidazole-functionalized PDI molecules to facilitate precise nanoscale size control. The metal-induced self-assembly was advisable for the control of the template size in a nanometer scale, along with the surface-exposed metal ions as nucleation sites, enabling the production of uniform 1D MOFs without other physical/chemical confinement. The self-assembly template method successfully produced uniform intact/carbonized ZIF-8 nanorods by providing heterogeneous nucleation sites for ZIF-8 growth along with sufficient resistance to thermal stress during the pyrolysis. The uniform, size-controllable bulk production of MOF nanorods under 100 nm using the self-assembly templates, along with the subsequent modification, has the potential to overcome the limitations (e.g., limited mass, requirement for additional process to remove templates) commonly faced by former (e.g., inorganic nanofiber) production methods. The excellent capacitor performance of the carbonized ZIF-8 nanorods as EDLC electrode materials justified the development of 1D ZIF-8 rods on the nanoscale. The remarkable EDLC properties of the ZIF-8 nanorods, compared to that of 0D nanoparticles, were explained by (i) the unique 1D architecture that reduces the interfacial resistance and facilitates the electron/ion transport through the hierarchically interconnected mesopores, and (ii) the enhancement of the intrinsic electrical conductivity derived from the N-doped carbon. In comparison to previous carbon nanorod preparation methods, the use of a self-assembly template and subsequent carbonization provided a simple procedure for the preparation of size-controlled porous N-doped carbon nanorods by controlling the self-assembly conditions and by exploiting the porous nature of ZIF-8 with imidazole groups. This versatile and effective synthetic strategy using the self-assembly of small building blocks opens up the opportunity for the synthesis of MOFs or other hybrid materials in complicated structures, thus meeting current scrupulous requirements for the fabrication of modern devices.

div.div:
For the synthesis of PDI-Hm, a mixture of perylene-3,4:9,10-tetracarboxylic dianhydride (0.98 g, 2.5 mmol), histamine dihydrochloride (0.83 g, 7.5 mmol), and imidazole (12 g) was heated at 140 °C under nitrogen for 24 h with stirring. After the reaction, the mixture was dissolved in 0.1 N HCl and filtered to remove the unreacted perylenetetracarboxylic dianhydride. The synthesized PDI-Hm was then precipitated by the addition of 1 N NaOH solution. The solid precipitates were washed with distilled water to remove the excess imidazole. After drying the precipitate at 70 °C in a vacuum oven, the crude solid powder was further purified by dispersing in dimethylformamide (DMF) solution to remove other unreacted starting materials. The solid in DMF was collected and washed twice with water and acetone. Finally, the solid PDI-Hm powder was dried under vacuum to obtain the purified product.

The PZ nanorods were carbonized under a nitrogen atmosphere via pyrolysis. The PZ nanorod was first heated at 2 °C min
–1

–1

2

The field-emission SEM (IT500HR, JEOL) and transmission electron microscope (JEM-1011, JEOL) were used for the morphological observation. Energy-filtered transmission electron microscopy (JEM-F200, JEOL) equipped with EDX (Inca, Oxford, UK) was used for the atomic mapping of nanorod samples. The crystalline structure of the samples was analyzed using an XRD analyzer (Ultima IV, Rigaku, Japan) equipped with a Cu Kα radiation source (λ = 1.542 Å). A Raman spectrometer (LabRam Aramis, HORIBA Jovin Yvon, Japan) and UV–vis spectrophotometer (S-3100, Scinco, Korea) were used for the spectroscopic analyses. An XPS (K-alpha, Thermo Scientific, USA) equipped with an Al Kα μ-focused monochromator (1486.6 eV) was used for the XPS analysis. The N
2
adsorption/desorption isotherms were obtained using a surface area and pore size analyzer (Autosorb-iQ 2ST/MP, Quantachrome) and the BET model was applied for the surface area calculations. The pore size distribution was determined from the non-local density functional theory model. The XRD pattern and stacking structure were optimized by direct space method which is implemented in Expo 2014 program.
(57)

The electrochemical characterizations were performed using a VSP potentiostat (Bio-Logic, USA). The as-prepared 1D PZC nanorods were mixed with polyvinylidene fluoride (GPC grade, Sigma-Aldrich) at a weight ratio of 95:5 using
N
-methyl-2-pyrrolidone as the solvent to form a slurry without the addition of other conductive agents. The prepared slurry was then pasted onto a clean 1 × 2 cm
2
carbon paper (SGL, GDL 39BC) with 0.5 mg cm
–2
of loading and dried at 70 °C for 1 day under vacuum. CV, galvanostatic charge–discharge (GCD), and EIS measurements were conducted in the 1 M H
2
SO

The EIS was performed under the same configuration with an amplitude of 5 mV from 0.5 MHz to 1 Hz. A one-pot solvothermal synthesis of ZIF-7 using Zn nitrate and benzimidazole at stoichiometric ratio (molar ratio 1:2) directly dissolved into a PEI-DMF soln. at room temp. is reported. The obtained colloidal soln. can be directly used as a seeding sol for the membrane fabrication. The crystal size and morphol. of MOF materials can be tailored to manipulate the orientation of MOF films through evolutionary selection in a van der Drift-type growth originating from randomly oriented seed layers.

One- and two-dimensional carbon nanomaterials are attracting considerable attention because of their extraordinary elec., mech. and thermal properties, which could lead to a range of important potential applications. Synthetic processes assocd. with making these materials can be quite complex and also consume large amts. of energy, so a major challenge is to develop simple and efficient methods to produce them. Here, we present a self-templated, catalyst-free strategy for the synthesis of one-dimensional carbon nanorods by morphol.-preserved thermal transformation of rod-shaped metal-org. frameworks. The as-synthesized non-hollow (solid) carbon nanorods can be transformed into two- to six-layered graphene nanoribbons through sonochem. treatment followed by chem. activation. The performance of these metal-org. framework-derived carbon nanorods and graphene nanoribbons in supercapacitor electrodes demonstrates that this synthetic approach can produce functionally useful materials. Moreover, this approach is readily scalable and could be used to produce carbon nanorods and graphene nanoribbons on industrial levels.

Carbon-based materials, as one of the most important electrode materials for supercapacitors, have attracted tremendous attention. At present, it is highly desirable but remains challenging to prep. one-dimensional carbon complex hollow nanomaterials for further improving the performance of supercapacitors. Herein, we report an effective strategy for the synthesis of hollow particle-based nitrogen-doped carbon nanofibers (HPCNFs-N). By embedding ultrafine zeolitic imidazolate framework (ZIF-8) nanoparticles into electrospun polyacrylonitrile (PAN), the as-prepd. composite nanofibers are carbonized into hierarchical porous nanofibers composed of interconnected nitrogen-doped carbon hollow nanoparticles. Owing to its unique structural feature and the desirable chem. compn., the derived HPCNFs-N material exhibits much enhanced electrochem. properties as an electrode material for supercapacitors with remarkable specific capacitance at various current densities, high energy/power d. and long cycling stability over 10 000 cycles.

The synthesis of zeolitic imidazole framework (ZIF-8) in water was systematically studied using 6 zinc sources (Zn(OAc)2, ZnSO4, Zn(NO3)2, ZnCl2, ZnBr2, ZnI2), resp., under different conditions at room temp. without using any additives. Zn(OAc)2 is the best precursor and the resultant ZIF-8 particles have the best quality with rhombic dodecahedron morphol. The concn. of 2-methylimidazole (Hmim), molar ratio Hmim/Zn and water content all have significant impacts on the morphol., particle size, and crystallinity of ZIF-8. Further result anal. reveals that 3 key reactions are involved in the ZIF-8 formation which needs five steps in ZIF-8 structural evolution. This study provides a deep understanding of the crystn. process of ZIF-8 particles in a water-based system.

Mol. sieving metal-org. framework (MOF) membranes have great potential for energy-efficient chem. sepns., but a major hurdle is the lack of a scalable and inexpensive membrane fabrication mechanism. We describe a route for processing MOF membranes in polymeric hollow fibers, combining a two-solvent interfacial approach for positional control over membrane formation (at inner and outer surfaces, or in the bulk, of the fibers), a microfluidic approach to replenishment or recycling of reactants, and an in situ module for membrane fabrication and permeation. We fabricated continuous mol. sieving ZIF-8 membranes in single and multiple poly(amide-imide) hollow fibers, with H2/C3H8 and C3H6/C3H8 sepn. factors as high as 370 and 12, resp. We also demonstrate positional control of the ZIF-8 films and characterize the contributions of membrane defects and lumen bypass.

Propylene/propane sepn. is one of the most challenging sepns., currently achieved by energy-intensive cryogenic distn. Despite the great potential for energy-efficient membrane-based sepns., no com. membranes are currently available due to the limitations of current polymeric materials. Zeolitic imidazolate framework, ZIF-8, with the effective aperture size of ∼4.0 Å, has been shown to be very promising for propylene/propane sepn. Despite the extensive research on ZIF-8 membranes, only a few reported ZIF-8 membranes have displayed good propylene/propane sepn. performances presumably due to the challenges of controlling the microstructures of polycryst. membranes. Here we report the first well-intergrown membranes of ZIF-67 (Co-substituted ZIF-8) by heteroepitaxially growing ZIF-67 on ZIF-8 seed layers. The ZIF-67 membranes exhibited impressively high propylene/propane sepn. capabilities. Furthermore, when a tertiary growth of ZIF-8 layers was applied to heteroepitaxially grown ZIF-67 membranes, the membranes exhibited unprecedentedly high propylene/propane sepn. factors of ∼200 possibly due to enhanced grain boundary structure.

A defect-free zeolitic imidazolate framework-8 (ZIF-8)/graphene oxide (GO) membrane with a thickness of 100 nm was prepd. using two-dimensional (2D) ZIF-8/GO hybrid nanosheets as seeds. Hybrid nanosheets with a suitable amt. of ZIF-8 nanocrystals were essential for producing a uniform seeding layer that facilitates fast crystal intergrowth during membrane formation. Moreover, the seeding layer acts as a barrier between two different synthesis solns., and self-limits crystal growth and effectively eliminates defects during the contra-diffusion process. The resulting ultrathin membranes show excellent mol. sieving gas sepn. properties, such as with a high CO2/N2 selectivity of 7.0. This 2D nano-hybrid seeding strategy can be readily extended to the fabrication of other defect-free and ultrathin MOF or zeolite mol. sieving membranes for a wide range of sepn. applications.

A microwave-antenna strategy was developed for the in situ synthesis of Cu nanowire (CuNW) threaded ZIF-8. The CuNWs acted as microwave-antennas to generate surface "super hot" dots. The high temp. of "super hot" dots induced adsorption and coordination of metal ions and org. ligands, followed by in situ assembly and crystal-growth along the CuNWs. This catalyst exhibited high activity and stability in H2 prodn. via NH3BH3 hydrolysis owing to the synergetic effect. The CuNWs supplied a rapid electron transfer channel while ZIF-8 assembled on the CuNWs offered a large capacity for adsorbing reactants and channels for rapidly transferring H-/H+ ions toward Cu active sites. Other one-dimensional threaded MOFs, including CuNW threaded MOF-5 and UIO-66, or carbon nanotube threaded ZIF-8 and ZIF-67 could also be prepd. using the microwave-antenna strategy.

When evaluated as anodes for lithium ion batteries,
[email protected]
/N-C exhibits an reversible capacity of 803 mAh g-1 at 50 mA g-1 after 100 cycles, excellent cyclability with a capacity of 595 mAh g-1 at 1000 mAg-1 after 200 cycles, as well as better rate capability compared with those non-N-C shelled manganese oxides (MnOx). The outstanding electrochem. performance is attributed to the unique yolk-shell nanorod structure, the coating effect of N-C and nanoscale size.

A review. Self-assembly of small mols. into one-dimensional nanostructures offers many potential applications in electronically and biol. active materials. The recent advances discussed in this account demonstrate how researchers can use the fundamental principles of supramol. chem. to craft the size, shape, and internal structure of nanoscale objects. In each system described here, we used at. force microscopy (AFM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) to study the assembly morphol. CD, NMR, IR, and optical spectroscopy provided addnl. information about the self-assembly behavior in soln. at the mol. level. Dendron rod-coil mols. self-assemble into flat or helical ribbons. They can incorporate electronically conductive groups and can be mineralized with inorg. semiconductors. To understand the relative importance of each segment in forming the supramol. structure, we synthetically modified the dendron, rod, and coil portions. The self-assembly depended on the generation no. of the dendron, the no. of hydrogen-bonding functions, and the length of the rod and coil segments. We formed chiral helixes using a dendron-rod-coil mol. prepd. from an enantiomerically enriched coil. Because helical nanostructures are important targets for use in biomaterials, nonlinear optics, and stereoselective catalysis, researchers would like to precisely control their shape and size. Tripeptide-contg. peptide lipid mols. assemble into straight or twisted nanofibers in org. solvents. As seen by AFM, the sterics of bulky end groups can tune the helical pitch of these peptide lipid nanofibers in org. solvents. Furthermore, we demonstrated the potential for pitch control using trans-to-cis photoisomerization of a terminal azobenzene group. Other mols. called peptide amphiphiles (PAs) are known to assemble in water into cylindrical nanostructures that appear as nanofiber bundles. Surprisingly, TEM of a PA substituted by a nitrobenzyl group revealed assembly into quadruple helical fibers with a braided morphol. Upon photocleavage of this the nitrobenzyl group, the helixes transform into single cylindrical nanofibers. Finally, inspired by the tobacco mosaic virus, we used a dumbbell-shaped, oligo(phenylene ethynylene) template to control the length of a PA nanofiber self-assembly (<10 nm). AFM showed complete disappearance of long nanofibers in the presence of this rigid-rod template. Results from quick-freeze/deep-etch TEM and dynamic light scattering demonstrated the templating behavior in aq. soln. This strategy could provide a general method to control size the length of nonspherical supramol. nanostructures.

Liljestrom Ville; Hassinen Jukka; Nonappa; Heilala Maria; Hynninen Ville; Ras Robin H A; Ikkala Olli; Kostiainen Mauri A; Liljestrom Ville; Ora Ari; Ras Robin H A; Kostiainen Mauri A; Rekola Heikki T; Torma Paivi; Joensuu Jussi J

Material properties depend critically on the packing and order of constituent units throughout length scales. Beyond classically explored molecular self-assembly, structure formation in the nanoparticle and colloidal length scales have recently been actively explored for new functions. Structure of colloidal assemblies depends strongly on the assembly process, and higher structural control can be reliably achieved only if the process is deterministic. Here we show that self-assembly of cationic spherical metal nanoparticles and anionic rod-like viruses yields well-defined binary superlattice wires. The superlattice structures are explained by a cooperative assembly pathway that proceeds in a zipper-like manner after nucleation. Curiously, the formed superstructure shows right-handed helical twisting due to the right-handed structure of the virus. This leads to structure-dependent chiral plasmonic function of the material. The work highlights the importance of well-defined colloidal units when pursuing unforeseen and complex assemblies.Colloidal self-assembly is a unique method to produce three-dimensional materials with well-defined hierarchical structures and functionalities. Liljestrom et al. show controlled preparation of macroscopic chiral wires with helical plasmonic superlattice structure composed of metal nanoparticles and viruses.

Carbon nanofibers (CNFs) have a wide range of applications and are commonly prepd. under harsh conditions with small quantities. A green method for the prepn. of CNFs under mild conditions with the scalable potential is highly challenging. Here, we describe a facile water-based room-temp. approach to producing gel fibers from a perylene diimide deriv. via self-assembly, gelation, freeze-drying, and then to generating CNFs by subsequent pyrolysis under Ar. The entangled CNFs, with relatively uniform diams. around 20-50 nm, can be prepd. as thin films or monoliths. The CNFs doped with elements N and Sn can be readily produced. The CNFs are characterized by various techniques and particularly evaluated as electrode materials for supercapacitor by cyclic voltammetry and galvanostatic charge-discharge. A non-ionic surfactant (Pluronics F-127) can be easily incorporated into the self-assembly process, which produces the CNFs with a higher surface area 520 m2 g-1 and a specific capacitance of 346 F g-1 at the scan rate of 1 mV s-1 or 192 F g-1 at the c.d. of 1 A g-1. The CNF electrodes are highly stable. Quite surprisingly, the specific capacitance increases with repeated testing, achieving an impressive 226 F g-1 for 1000 charge/discharge cycles at 4 A g-1.

The self-organizing structures formed by a water-sol. perylene diimide dye (PDI) were studied by several exptl. techniques as potential templates for the prepn. of hybrid nanomaterials. The dye forms chromonic-nematic and hexagonal liq. crystals in water. The aggregates in liq. crystals consist of 1-mol.-wide stacks. From the changes in the soln. 1H NMR chem. shifts with concn., it appears that adjacent mols. are twisted. There is significant broadening of the arom. resonances at higher concns., arising from nonmotionally averaged dipole-dipole coupling between adjacent arom. hydrogens. This is attributed to slow overall rotation of the aggregates in soln., suggesting that they grow up to several tens of nanometers. Dye aggregates serve as templates for the formation of silica tubules (1-5 μm length, av. diam. ≈300 nm), with aligned and very thin (1-2 nm) dye nanostripes embedded in the walls. The silica tubes pptd. from soln. are formed by the cooperative interaction between PDI and silica species during the sol-gel reaction. Upon calcination, silica nanotubules with supermicroporous walls are obtained. In comparison with conventional surfactant systems, the use of π-π stacked chromonic aggregates brings new possibilities for the templated fabrication of pores with sizes below the mesoporous range. Materials could find applications in photovoltaics as well as in shape selective catalysis and adsorption.

A new type of bolaamphiphile bearing pyridinium-alkoxy bipyrimidine, [5,5'-(RO)2-2,2'-bipyrimidine]Cl2 [R = C5H5N+(CH2)8; bpym-8] was designed and prepd. The bipyrimidine moiety allows for metal-ligand coordination, thereby influencing the self-assembly of the bolaamphiphile. Before coordination, bpym-8 self-assembles in water to form spherical aggregates. An interesting finding is that the coordination of the Cu(II) ion with bipyrimidine can induce the assembly of bpym-8 to change from spheres to clustered aggregates. It should be noted that the assembly of bpym-8 can be reversibly converted back by removing the Cu(II) ion from the coordination. This study presents a new type of bolaamphiphile that is able to coordinate with metal ions, which may provide a new clue in fabricating reversibly tunable supramol. nanomaterials.

Ever since the axial chiral catalysts were developed for asym. reactions with excellent chiral discrimination and high efficiencies, the interest in the supramol. catalyst has also been extensively investigated. Here, with a hint from the typical mol. catalyst, we developed a series of metal-coordinated nanotube (M-helical nanotube, M-HN) catalysts for asym. reactions. The M-HN catalyst was fabricated on the basis of the self-assembly of an L-glutamic acid terminated bolaamphiphile, which formed a single-walled nanotube. On one hand, through the coordination of transition metal ions with the carboxylic acid groups on the nanotube surface, a wide variety of single-walled M-HN catalysts could be fabricated, in which the coordination sites could serve as the catalytic sites. On the other hand, using a slight amt. of these catalysts, significant reactivity and enantioselectivity were realized for certain asym. reactions under mild conditions. Remarkably, Bi(III)-HN could catalyze the asym. Mukaiyama aldol reaction with high enantioselectivity (up to 97% ee) in an aq. system; Cu(II)-HN catalyzed the asym. Diels-Alder reaction with up to 91% ee within 60 min. It was suggested that a synergetic effect of the aligned multicatalytic sites and stereochem. selectivity of the M-HN lead to an excellent catalytic performance. Through this work, we proposed a new concept of a single-walled nanotube as catalyst and showed the first example of nanotube catalysts presenting high reactivity and enantioselectivity that rivaled a chiral mol. catalyst.

The ir spectra of imidazole and imidazolium ion in D2O have been assigned on the basis of isotopic substitution results. Spectral changes attendant on coordination of imidazole and α-alanine with bivalent metal ions in D2O have been observed. Formation consts. for monodentate coordination of alanine at lower pD values have been evaluated. The results for imidazole and alanine are employed in interpreting the ir spectrum of L-histidine in D2O as a function of pD. The structures of metal-histidine complexes as a function of soln. pD have been inferred from ir data, which indicate the presence of monodentate, bidentate, and tridentate 1:1 histidine complexes at various levels of soln. acidity. At pD > 11 a histidine complex is formed which involves coordination to the amino group and the deprotonated (anionic) imidazole moiety. The pD dependence of the ir spectra provides information relating to the formation consts. for complex formation; the magnitudes of certain frequency shifts provide information which relates to the enthalpy of formation of the coordinate bond. In particular, the shift in frequency of the antisymmetric carboxylate stretching mode on coordination at the α-amino group is related to the strength of the metal-amino group interaction.

Directing self-assembly processes out-of-equil. to yield kinetically trapped materials with well-defined dimensions remains a considerable challenge. Kinetically controlled assembly of self-synthesizing peptide-functionalized macrocyclic compds. through a nucleation-growth mechanism is reported. Spontaneous fiber formation in this system is effectively shut down as most of the material is diverted into metastable non-assembling trimeric and tetrameric macrocyclic compds. However, upon adding seeds to this mixt., well-defined fibers with controllable lengths and narrow polydispersity are obtained. This seeded growth strategy also allows access to supramol. triblock copolymers. The resulting noncovalent assemblies can be further stabilized through covalent capture. Taken together, these results show that self-synthesizing materials, through their interplay between dynamic covalent bonds and noncovalent interactions, are uniquely suited for out-of-equil. self-assembly. The synthesis of the target compds. was achieved by a cyclization of N-(3,5-dimercaptobenzoyl)glycyl-L-leucyl-L-lysyl-L-phenylalanyl-L-lysine. The title compds. thus formed included a trimer-peptide-conjugate [2,3,9,10,16,17-hexathiatetracyclo[16.3.1.14,8.111,15]tetracosa-1(22),4,6,8(24),11,13,15(23),18,20-nonaene], tetramer-peptide-conjugate and hexamer-peptide-conjugate.

The development of org. supramol. photocatalytic materials requires a deeper understanding of the structure-activity relationship. Herein, the effects of H/J-type stacking on the photocatalytic mechanism and activity of PDI have been investigated. As a face-to-face arrangement, H-aggregates have higher π-electron conjugation and show more semiconductor characteristics, which results in higher carrier sepn. and migration efficiency under irradn. Whereas, J-aggregates exhibit more mol. properties due to its low π-electron conjugation caused by head-to-tail stacking mode. As a result, H-aggregated PDI mainly forms superoxide radicals (·O-2) and holes (h+) through electron-transfer (ET). In contrast, J-aggregated PDI mainly generates singlet oxygen species (1O2) via energy-transfer (EnT). Benefit from the stronger oxidizability of ·O-2 and h+, H-aggregated PDI shows higher photocatalytic activity for small mol. degrdn. and oxygen evolution under visible light. Whereas, J-aggregated PDI exhibits potential application in photocatalytic anti-cancer treatment owing to its high 1O2 quantum yields (0.66) under red light radiation. Our findings may provide a guidance for the development of supramol. org. photocatalytic materials.

The phase behavior of three N-alkyl-substituted perylene diimide derivs. was examd. by DSC and polarized optical microscopy. The occurrence of multiple phase transitions indicates several cryst. and several liq. cryst. phases. x-ray diffraction measurements show that the liq. cryst. phases display high structural ordering in all three dimensions: smectic layers are formed, and within these smectic layers an addnl. ordering in columns is obsd. Mol. modeling confirms this result and substantiates smectic ordering with interdigitating alkyl chains that det. the distance between the smectic layers. The ordering in columns is favored by π-π interactions between the cofacially oriented perylene mols. and by the elliptic shape of the mol. Finally, intermol. dipole-dipole interactions between the carbonyl groups of the imide moieties cause the perylene mols. to orient on av. with a slight rotation between neighboring mols. within a columnar stack. Following the detn. of the electronic transition dipole moment, this orientation, which still involves substantial π-π interactions, could be confirmed by UV/visible spectroscopy of perylene aggregates. To gauge the potential of these materials as org. semiconductors, the charge carrier mobility of one of the perylene derivs. was measured by pulse-radiolysis time-resolved microwave cond. A value >0.1 cm2 V-1 s-1 is found in the liq. cryst. phase, and a value >0.2 cm2 V-1 s-1 is found for the cryst. phase. These values are comparable with the highest values previously found for other discotic materials.

The aggregation was investigated of a cyanine dye which is a particularly clear exptl. example for the formation of aggregates with blue-shifted absorption bands. The large aggregates have been observed by electron microscopy, optical microscopy, x-ray diffraction, and absorption spectroscopy. The sep. absorption bands of smaller aggregates up to the pentamer have been clearly resolved and have been identified by semiquant. use of the mol. exciton model. These resolved bands form a regular wavelength progression leading up to a band head for very large aggregates located 100 mμ from the monomer peak. The dye in question is 3,3'-bis(β-carboxyethyl)-5,5'-dichloro-9-methylthiacarbocyanine, a photographic sensitizer. All of the exptl. results are consistent with a deck-of-cards structure for the aggregates, with the long axes of mols. perpendicular to the axis of the aggregate. Counterions are not incorporated in the space between mol. planes, since the wave lengths of the band head and the resolved low-polymer bands are all insensitive to the identity of the counterion. 17 references.

Different optically active and inactive derivs. of the perylene dye, perylene-3,4:9,10-tetracarboxylic bisimide, solubilized in unilamellar lipid vesicles of 1,2-dioleoyl-sn-glycero-3-phosphocholine (DOPC) were studied by polarized light spectroscopic methods. Absorption and fluorescence spectra become distorted at molar ratios >1 dye mol. per 1000 mols. of DOPC. These observations are compatible with the formation of ground-state aggregates. CD was not detectable for any perylene dye dissolved in liq. solns., or dild. in lipid vesicles. However, dyes with optically active substituents reveal CD spectra at dye:lipid ratios of >1:1000. For dyes with R and S enantiomers, CD spectra are mirror images, while no CD of racemic mixts., or optically inactive perylene dyes could be detected. The obsd. absorption and CD spectra are qual. explained by exciton coupling within dimers and their mol. symmetry.

A series of 5 perylenetetracarboxylic acid bisimides bearing 3,4,5-tris(dodecyloxy)phenyl substituents on the imide N atoms and zero, two, or four phenoxy-type substituents in the bay positions of the perylene core were synthesized. From investigations of their spectroscopic properties and aggregation behavior in low-polarity solvents by absorption and fluorescence optical spectroscopy, not only were these compds. found to form fluorescent J-type aggregates, but also binding consts. for aggregation could be derived which reflect the no. and steric demand of the phenoxy substituents for four of the bisimides (with 4-alkylphenoxy substituents in the bay positions). In the pristine state, these 4 form thermotropic hexagonal columnar mesophases which exist over a broad temp. range from below -30°C to over +300°C. For the compd. with only PhO in the bay positions, however, a layered cryst. structure was found. This difference in behavior can be explained by the concept of microphase segregation of the arom. cores of the mols. and the alkyl chains at the periphery. The high stability and bright fluorescence of the mesophase of several of the compds. make them promising for applications as polarizers or components in (opto)electronic devices.

Constructing Z-scheme system is a promising way to fabricate efficient photocatalysts for solar light utilization. In this study, a novel all-solid direct Z-scheme photocatalyst PTCDA-C3N4 was synthesized and characterized by several methods. XRD and HRTEM confirmed the strong π-π interaction between PTCDA(Perylene-3,4,9,10-tetracarboxylic dianhydride) and g-C3N4 induced the crystal transformation of PTCDA from β-phase to α-phase, self-assembling and reconstructing into nanocryst. of 5 nm. UV-vis and photoelectronic measurements illustrated that the coupling of PTCDA on g-C3N4 not only dramatically broadened visible light absorption, but also accelerated the charge transfer of g-C3N4. Both the theor. calcn. and active species trapping expts. verified the Z-scheme mechanism of PTCDA-C3N4 heterostructure, which endows the hole of PTCDA-C3N4 much strong oxidizability and effective electron-hole sepn., thus eight times higher activity than that of pristine g-C3N4 for benzylamine oxidn. under solar driven. Our current work paves a facile way for synthesis efficient Z-scheme photocatalysts.

The existence is revealed of 2 different cryst. phases, i.e., the metastable rock salt and the equil. Zn blende phase within the CdS-shell of PbS/CdS core/shell nanocrystals formed by cationic exchange. The chem. compn. profile of the core/shell nanocrystals with different dimensions is detd. by anomalous small-angle x-ray scattering with sub-nm resoln. and is compared to x-ray diffraction anal. The luminescence emission of PbS nanocrystals can be drastically enhanced by the formation of a CdS shell. The ratio of the 2 cryst. phases in the shell significantly influences the luminescence enhancement. The highest emission was achieved for CP CdS shells <1 nm thickness with a dominant metastable rock salt phase fraction matching the crystal structure of the PbS core. The metastable phase fraction decreases with increasing shell thickness and increasing exchange times. The luminescence intensity depicts a const. decrease with decreasing metastable rock salt phase fraction but shows an abrupt drop for shells >1.3 nm thickness. This effect is related to 2 different transition mechanisms for changing from the metastable rock salt phase to the equil. Zn blende phase depending on the shell thickness.

The prepn. of one-dimensional carbon materials with complex dual-scale nanostructures for supercapacitor applications still remains a challenge. Herein we report a simple strategy for electrosynthesis of silicon carbide nanowire (SiC NW)-derived carbon with dual-scale nanostructures for high performance supercapacitors. This method is highlighted by using solid oxide membrane technol. to directly convert powd. silicon dioxide/carbon precursors into SiC NWs, and then the synthesized SiC NWs are further transformed into mesoporous silicon carbide-derived carbon nanowires (SiC-CDC NWs) via a subsequent in situ molten salt electrochem. etching process. Benefitting from their dual-scale nanostructures, these SiC-CDC NWs exhibit highly reversible specific capacitance of 260 F/g at 1 A/g and good cyclability (97.9% after 5000 cycles) in 6 M KOH aq. soln. without the need for doping the SiC-CDC NWs. It is suggested that this process is a promising general approach for synthesizing CDC materials with dual-scale nanostructures for energy storage applications.

Heteroatom-doped carbon nanostructures with uniform size and morphol., well-designed architectures, and minimized interfacial resistance have been recognized as promising electrode materials for energy storage, but remain a crucial challenge. Herein, we develop a general approach of polarity-induced decoration of a monolayer sheath of metal-org. framework (MOF) particles with excellent uniformity in size and morphol. on electrospun polymer nanofibers. These hybrid nanofibers are facilely converted into nitrogen-doped nanofibrous carbon (denoted as N-NFC) during pyrolysis. The thus-obtained N-NFC features (1) a one-dimensional nanofibrous structure with a highly conductive core, (2) a monolayer sheath of hollow carbon-frames with uniform size and morphol., (3) plenty of micro/mesopores with a highly accessible surface area, and (4) a high N-doping level, all of which guarantee its good electrochem. performance with a high capacitance of 387.3 F g-1 at 1 A g-1. In a solid-state supercapacitor, it delivers excellent rate capability (78.0 F g-1 at 0.2 A g-1 and 64.0 F g-1 at 1 A g-1), an enhanced energy d. of 7.9 W h kg-1 at a power d. of 219 W kg-1, and outstanding cycling stability with 90% capacity retained over 10 000 cycles at 1 A g-1.

Nitrogen (N)-doped carbon materials exhibit high electrocatalytic activity for the oxygen redn. reaction (ORR), which is essential for several renewable energy systems. However, the ORR active site (or sites) is unclear, which retards further developments of high-performance catalysts. Here, we characterized the ORR active site by using newly designed graphite (highly oriented pyrolytic graphite) model catalysts with well-defined π conjugation and well-controlled doping of N species. The ORR active site is created by pyridinic N. Carbon dioxide adsorption expts. indicated that pyridinic N also creates Lewis basic sites. The specific activities per pyridinic N in the HOPG model catalysts are comparable with those of N-doped graphene powder catalysts. Thus, the ORR active sites in N-doped carbon materials are carbon atoms with Lewis basicity next to pyridinic N.

In this study, we report self-assembled nitrogen-doped fullerenes (N-fullerene) as non-precious catalysts, which are active for the oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER), and thus applicable for energy conversion and storage devices such as fuel cells and metal-air battery systems. Quinones are attractive redox-active starting materials due to their excellent electron transfer kinetics and outstanding redox reversibility, while amines featuring high electron-pair donicity reinforce the redox behavior of quinones and simultaneously introduce redox groups themselves. Herein, a novel quinone-amine route is designed to fabricate N, O codoped porous carbon nanospheres (PCNs) by direct carbonization-activation of a quinone-amine polymer which serves as an "all-in-one" precursor for the carbon source and self-dopant. The synthesis features simplicity, high efficiency and scale-up potential, based on the polymn. of p-benzoquinone and 3,3'-diaminobenzidine in ethanol under mild conditions, without any template, complicated technique or tedious procedure. The PCNs integrate the superiorities of uniform spherical geometry, superior pore structure, and ultrahigh surface area and N/O content. A typical PCN electrode exhibits a high capacitance (376 F g-1 at 0.5 A g-1 in a three-electrode system) in KOH electrolyte. The assembled supercapacitor based on the PCN electrode and KOH electrolyte delivers a capacitance of 72.5 F g-1 and an energy output of 6.5 W h kg-1. More importantly, a constructed sym. supercapacitor using an ionic liq. gel electrolyte gives an ultrahigh energy d. ≤ 65.8 W h kg-1, along with superb cycling stability. This study presents a more convenient and competitive route to design functionalized carbons for highly efficient energy storage.

Chen, Li-Feng; Zhang, Xu-Dong; Liang, Hai-Wei; Kong, Mingguang; Guan, Qing-Fang; Chen, Ping; Wu, Zhen-Yu; Yu, Shu-Hong

Supercapacitors (also known as ultracapacitors) are considered to be the most promising approach to meet the pressing requirements of energy storage. Supercapacitive electrode materials, which are closely related to the high-efficiency storage of energy, have provoked more interest. Herein, we present a high-capacity supercapacitor material based on the nitrogen-doped porous carbon nanofibers synthesized by carbonization of macroscopic-scale carbonaceous nanofibers coated with polypyrrole at an appropriate temp. The composite nanofibers exhibit a reversible sp. capacitance of 202.0 F/g at the c.d. of 1.0 A/g in 6.0 mol/L aq. KOH electrolyte, meanwhile maintaining a high-class capacitance retention capability and a max. power d. of 89.57 kW/kg. This kind of nitrogen-doped carbon nanofiber represents an alternative promising candidate for an efficient electrode material for supercapacitors.

Cellulose Nanofiber @ Conductive Metal-Organic Frameworks for High-Performance Flexible Supercapacitors
Zhou, Shengyang; Kong, Xueying; Zheng, Bing; Huo, Fengwei; Stroemme, Maria; Xu, Chao

Conductive metal-org. frameworks (c-MOFs) show great potential in electrochem. energy storage thanks to their high elec. cond. and highly accessible surface areas. However, there are significant challenges in processing c-MOFs for practical applications. Here, we report on the fabrication of c-MOF nanolayers on cellulose nanofibers (CNFs) with formation of nanofibrillar
[email protected]
by interfacial synthesis, in which CNFs serve as substrates for growth of c-MOF nanolayers. The obtained hybrid nanofibers of
[email protected]
can be easily assembled into freestanding nanopapers, demonstrating high elec. cond. of up to 100 S cm-1, hierarchical micromesoporosity, and excellent mech. properties. Given these advantages, the nanopapers are tested as electrodes in a flexible and foldable supercapacitor. The high cond. and hierarchical porous structure of the electrodes endow fast charge transfer and efficient electrolyte transport, resp. Furthermore, the assembled supercapacitor shows extremely high cycle stability with capacitance retentions of >99% after 10000 continuous charge-discharge cycles. This work provides a pathway to develop flexible energy storage devices based on sustainable cellulose and MOFs.

A review. This tutorial review provides a brief summary of recent research progress on carbon-based electrode materials for supercapacitors, as well as the importance of electrolytes in the development of supercapacitor technol. The basic principles of supercapacitors, the characteristics and performances of various nanostructured carbon-based electrode materials are discussed. Aq. and nonaq. electrolyte solns. used in supercapacitors are compared. The trend on future development of high-power and high-energy supercapacitors is analyzed.

Conductive MOF electrodes for stable supercapacitors with high areal capacitance
Sheberla, Dennis; Bachman, John C.; Elias, Joseph S.; Sun, Cheng-Jun; Shao-Horn, Yang; Dinca, Mircea
Nature Materials
(

Nature Publishing Group

Owing to their high power d. and superior cyclability relative to batteries, electrochem. double layer capacitors (EDLCs) have emerged as an important elec. energy storage technol. that will play a crit. role in the large-scale deployment of intermittent renewable energy sources, smart power grids, and elec. vehicles. Because the capacitance and charge-discharge rates of EDLCs scale with surface area and elec. cond., resp., porous carbons such as activated carbon, carbon nanotubes and crosslinked or holey graphenes are used exclusively as the active electrode materials in EDLCs. One class of materials whose surface area far exceeds that of activated carbons, potentially allowing them to challenge the dominance of carbon electrodes in EDLCs, is metal-org. frameworks (MOFs). The high porosity of MOFs, however, is conventionally coupled to very poor elec. cond., which has thus far prevented the use of these materials as active electrodes in EDLCs. Here, we show that Ni3(2,3,6,7,10,11-hexaiminotriphenylene)2 (Ni3(HITP)2), a MOF with high elec. cond., can serve as the sole electrode material in an EDLC. This is the first example of a supercapacitor made entirely from neat MOFs as active materials, without conductive additives or other binders. The MOF-based device shows an areal capacitance that exceeds those of most carbon-based materials and capacity retention greater than 90% over 10,000 cycles, in line with com. devices. Given the established structural and compositional tunability of MOFs, these results herald the advent of a new generation of supercapacitors whose active electrode materials can be tuned rationally, at the mol. level.

Li, Yanjiang; Zhu, Guang; Huang, Hailong; Xu, Min; Lu, Ting; Pan, Likun

Currently, electrospun carbon nanofibers (ECNFs) have attracted much attention due to their flexibility and easy fabrication. However, ECNFs generally show poor elec. cond., greatly limiting their practical application. In this work, flexible hierarchically porous carbon polyhedra embedded carbon nanofibers doped with N and S (NSCPCNF) were synthesized by electrospinning a metal-org. framework ZIF-67 and a thiourea incorporated polyacrylonitrile precursor with subsequent carbonization. Due to the enhanced sp. surface area, improved charge transfer ability and pseudocapacitive contribution by N, S dual doping, the as-obtained NSCPCNF shows a much higher specific capacitance of 396 F g-1 at a c.d. of 1 A g-1 in 1 mol L-1 H2SO4 electrolyte (three-electrode mode) than that of ECNFs (192 F g-1). More importantly, a flexible supercapacitor (FSC) assembled using NSCPCNF electrodes achieves a high specific capacitance of 103 F g-1 at a c.d. of 0.5 A g-1 (two-electrode mode), and a high energy d. of 14.3 W h kg-1 at a power d. of 250 W kg-1, which outperforms most of the reported ECNF based FSCs, and it also exhibits a high capacitance retention (107% of the initial value after 3000 charge-discharge cycles) and superior bending stability. The strategy proposed in this work provides the feasibility to explore high-performance flexible electrode materials for FSCs.

The effect of pore size distribution on the frequency dispersion of porous electrodes
Song, Hyun-Kon; Hwang, Hee-Young; Lee, Kun-Hong; Dao, Le H.

The transmission line model with pore size distribution (TLM-PSD) developed for blocking electrodes without faradaic reactions in our previous work was reformulated on the basis of the distribution of the penetrability coeff. α0, which is a more generalized concept than the distribution of pore size. Impedances were simulated using the TLM-PSD model for four different pore size distributions (PSD). Although different shapes of the Nyquist curve was obtained depending upon the different PSD, all simulated impedances share a common point that an increase in the width of a distribution (Pσ) leads to a more inclined Nyquist curve at high penetrability (αμ). This is because the effect of small pores on the total impedance increases with Pσ. We fitted the exptl. impedance data of a carbon membrane with the TLM-PSDs and the de Levie's model (TLM-δ). The fitting by TLM-PSD was successful while TLM-δ could not describe the impedance of the porous electrode at low frequency range. In addn., the geometric parameters estd. by TLM-PSD agreed with phys. available values.

Gong, Yujiao; Chen, Ruyi; Xu, Hai; Yu, Chenyang; Zhao, Xi; Sun, Yue; Hui, Zengyu; Zhou, Jinyuan; An, Jianing; Du, Zhuzhu; Sun, Gengzhi; Huang, Wei

Heteroatom-doped carbon nanostructures with uniform size and morphol., well-designed architectures, and minimized interfacial resistance have been recognized as promising electrode materials for energy storage, but remain a crucial challenge. Herein, we develop a general approach of polarity-induced decoration of a monolayer sheath of metal-org. framework (MOF) particles with excellent uniformity in size and morphol. on electrospun polymer nanofibers. These hybrid nanofibers are facilely converted into nitrogen-doped nanofibrous carbon (denoted as N-NFC) during pyrolysis. The thus-obtained N-NFC features (1) a one-dimensional nanofibrous structure with a highly conductive core, (2) a monolayer sheath of hollow carbon-frames with uniform size and morphol., (3) plenty of micro/mesopores with a highly accessible surface area, and (4) a high N-doping level, all of which guarantee its good electrochem. performance with a high capacitance of 387.3 F g-1 at 1 A g-1. In a solid-state supercapacitor, it delivers excellent rate capability (78.0 F g-1 at 0.2 A g-1 and 64.0 F g-1 at 1 A g-1), an enhanced energy d. of 7.9 W h kg-1 at a power d. of 219 W kg-1, and outstanding cycling stability with 90% capacity retained over 10 000 cycles at 1 A g-1.

RAMM: a new random-model-based method for solving ab initio crystal structure using the EXPO package
Altomare, Angela; Cuocci, Corrado; Moliterni, Anna; Rizzi, Rosanna
Journal of Applied Crystallography
(

.

International Union of Crystallography

The new method RAMM (random-model-based method) was developed and implemented in the EXPO computing program for improving the ab initio crystal structure soln. process. When the available information consists of only the exptl. powder diffraction pattern and the chem. formula of the compd. under study, the classical structure soln. approach follows two main steps: (1) phasing by direct methods (or by Patterson methods) to obtain a structure model (this last is usually incomplete and/or approx.); (2) improving the model by structure optimization techniques. This article proposes the alternative procedure RAMM, which skips step (1) and supplies a fully random model to step (2). This model is then submitted to effective structure optimization tools present in EXPO - wLSQ (weighted least squares), RBM (resoln. bias minimization) and COVMAP (a procedure of electron d. modification based on the concept of covariance between points of the map) - which are able to lead to the correct structure. RAMM is based on a cyclic process, generating several random models which are then optimized. The process stops automatically when it recognizes the correct structure.

A one-pot solvothermal synthesis of ZIF-7 using Zn nitrate and benzimidazole at stoichiometric ratio (molar ratio 1:2) directly dissolved into a PEI-DMF soln. at room temp. is reported. The obtained colloidal soln. can be directly used as a seeding sol for the membrane fabrication. The crystal size and morphol. of MOF materials can be tailored to manipulate the orientation of MOF films through evolutionary selection in a van der Drift-type growth originating from randomly oriented seed layers.

One- and two-dimensional carbon nanomaterials are attracting considerable attention because of their extraordinary elec., mech. and thermal properties, which could lead to a range of important potential applications. Synthetic processes assocd. with making these materials can be quite complex and also consume large amts. of energy, so a major challenge is to develop simple and efficient methods to produce them. Here, we present a self-templated, catalyst-free strategy for the synthesis of one-dimensional carbon nanorods by morphol.-preserved thermal transformation of rod-shaped metal-org. frameworks. The as-synthesized non-hollow (solid) carbon nanorods can be transformed into two- to six-layered graphene nanoribbons through sonochem. treatment followed by chem. activation. The performance of these metal-org. framework-derived carbon nanorods and graphene nanoribbons in supercapacitor electrodes demonstrates that this synthetic approach can produce functionally useful materials. Moreover, this approach is readily scalable and could be used to produce carbon nanorods and graphene nanoribbons on industrial levels.

Carbon-based materials, as one of the most important electrode materials for supercapacitors, have attracted tremendous attention. At present, it is highly desirable but remains challenging to prep. one-dimensional carbon complex hollow nanomaterials for further improving the performance of supercapacitors. Herein, we report an effective strategy for the synthesis of hollow particle-based nitrogen-doped carbon nanofibers (HPCNFs-N). By embedding ultrafine zeolitic imidazolate framework (ZIF-8) nanoparticles into electrospun polyacrylonitrile (PAN), the as-prepd. composite nanofibers are carbonized into hierarchical porous nanofibers composed of interconnected nitrogen-doped carbon hollow nanoparticles. Owing to its unique structural feature and the desirable chem. compn., the derived HPCNFs-N material exhibits much enhanced electrochem. properties as an electrode material for supercapacitors with remarkable specific capacitance at various current densities, high energy/power d. and long cycling stability over 10 000 cycles.

Mol. sieving metal-org. framework (MOF) membranes have great potential for energy-efficient chem. sepns., but a major hurdle is the lack of a scalable and inexpensive membrane fabrication mechanism. We describe a route for processing MOF membranes in polymeric hollow fibers, combining a two-solvent interfacial approach for positional control over membrane formation (at inner and outer surfaces, or in the bulk, of the fibers), a microfluidic approach to replenishment or recycling of reactants, and an in situ module for membrane fabrication and permeation. We fabricated continuous mol. sieving ZIF-8 membranes in single and multiple poly(amide-imide) hollow fibers, with H2/C3H8 and C3H6/C3H8 sepn. factors as high as 370 and 12, resp. We also demonstrate positional control of the ZIF-8 films and characterize the contributions of membrane defects and lumen bypass.
